title: How Our Toothbrushes Are Littering Paradise - The New York Times
body: How Our Toothbrushes Are Littering Paradise. A new survey of remote islands off the coast of Australia found mountains of plastic weighing as much as a blue whale. A new survey estimates the Cocos ...
readable_content: - The New York Times (2019-05-16): A new survey estimates the Cocos Keeling Islands are covered in more than 400 million pieces of plastic. The island chain, located off the coast of Australia, is popular with vacationing Australians due to its pristine beaches and beautiful oceans. However, a recent survey found that the islands are covered in a significant amount of plastic waste, with the total estimated to be more than 400 million pieces. This issue brings attention to the global problem of plastic pollution and its impact on even the most remote and seemingly pristine locations.
summary:
The prevalence of over 400 million pieces of plastic on the Cocos Keeling Islands is a concerning issue, shedding light on the pervasive problem of plastic pollution even in remote areas. This emphasizes the urgent need for global action to address plastic waste and its impact on the environment.

Sentiment: 0.9
